body:
I'm currently working on it on my branch if you want to take a look.
https://github.com/FaustXVI/assertj-core/tree/issue-312
I'm trying to to it all in one so it's allow me to see much of the code.

Do we also want the tests to be os agnostic ?
If not, i did it with an ugly hack in util.Strings.
If yes, then I we'll have to call String.format for each tests right ?

Yes the tests should be OS agnostics.
Can you create a PR ? It's easier to see what you have changed.
I disagree closing this issue, the tests are still os dependant.
The test code still use \n characters so they won't pass on a windows. Event if the production code is now OS agnostic, the build still is.

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.title: Problem with AbstractAssert.overridingErrorMessage when no arg is provided

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary

This is an old issue (#35) that was fixed in commit [44648c3d](https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/commit/44648c3d95ac678dc977ebca3866b96c63a1cb08), but broken again with the commit [932339d2](https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/commit/932339d2166ed776d0d7e375a3f8358e88d833f8#diff-b524f46f2b3f708cdd6ef17afbae1916) fixing #312 : 

Even though the overriding message has no arguments, it might contain `%` character that will be interpreted as a specifier marker, and will break the message. 

#### Example

```java
assertThat(true)
    .overridingErrorMessage("This will break 100% of the time")
    .isFalse();
```
